      11. 11
        Barrett, M. P.; Gemmell, C. G.; Suckling, C. J. Minor groove binders as anti-infective agents. Pharmacol. Ther. 2013, 139, 12– 23,  DOI: 10.1016/j.pharmthera.2013.03.002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Minor groove binders as anti-infective agents
        Barrett, Michael P.; Gemmell, Curtis G.; Suckling, Colin J.
        Pharmacology & Therapeutics (2013), 139 (1), 12-23CODEN: PHTHDT; ISSN:0163-7258. (Elsevier)
        A review. Minor groove binders are small mols. that form strong complexes with the minor groove of DNA. There are several structural types of which distamycin and netropsin analogs, oligoamides built from heterocyclic and arom. amino acids, and bis-amidines sepd. by arom. and heterocyclic rings are of particular pharmaceutical interest. These mols. have helical topol. that approx. matches the curvature of DNA in the minor groove. Depending upon the precise structure of the minor groove binder, selectivity can be obtained with respect to the DNA base sequence to which the compd. binds. Minor groove binders have found substantial applications in anti-cancer therapy but their significance in anti-infective therapy has also been significant and is growing. For example, compds. of the bis-amidine class have been notable contributors to antiparasitic therapy for many years with examples such as berenil and pentamidine being well-known. A recent growth area has been increased sophistication in the oligoamide class. High sequence selectivity is now possible and compds. with distinct antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, and antiparasitic activity have all been identified. Importantly, the structures of the most active compds. attacking the various infective organisms differ significantly but not necessarily predictively. This poses interesting questions of mechanism of action with many different targets involved in DNA processing being candidates. Access of compds. to specific cell types also plays a role and in some cases, can be decisive. Prospects for a range of selective therapeutic agents from this class of compds. are higher now than for some considerable time.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmt1Cnsrg%253D&md5=1440ebdaa5c53cc1be9160644f0e9f4a
      12. 12
        Kurmis, A. A.; Yang, F.; Welch, T. R.; Nickols, N. G.; Dervan, P. B. A pyrrole-imidazole polyamide is active against enzalutamide-resistant prostate cancer. Cancer Res. 2017, 77, 2207– 2212,  DOI: 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-16-2503
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        A Pyrrole-Imidazole Polyamide Is Active against Enzalutamide-Resistant Prostate Cancer
        Kurmis, Alexis A.; Yang, Fei; Welch, Timothy R.; Nickols, Nicholas G.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Cancer Research (2017), 77 (9), 2207-2212CODEN: CNREA8; ISSN:0008-5472. (American Association for Cancer Research)
        The LREX' prostate cancer model is resistant to the antiandrogen enzalutamide via activation of an alternative nuclear hormone receptor, glucocorticoid receptor (GR), which has similar DNA-binding specificity to the androgen receptor (AR). Small mols. that target DNA to interfere with protein-DNA interactions may retain activity against enzalutamide-resistant prostate cancers where ligand-binding domain antagonists are ineffective. We reported previously that a pyrrole-imidazole (Py-Im) polyamide designed to bind the consensus androgen response element half-site has antitumor activity against hormone-sensitive prostate cancer. In enzalutamide-resistant LREX' cells, Py-Im polyamide interfered with both AR- and GR-driven gene expression, whereas enzalutamide interfered with only that of AR. Genomic analyses indicated immediate interference with the AR transcriptional pathway. Long-term treatment with Py-Im polyamide demonstrated a global decrease in RNA levels consistent with inhibition of transcription. The polyamide was active against two enzalutamide-resistant xenografts with minimal toxicity. Overall, our results identify Py-Im polyamide as a promising therapeutic strategy in enzalutamide-resistant prostate cancer. Cancer Res; 77(9); 2207-12. ©2017 AACR.

        13
        An evaluation of Minor Groove Binders as anti-lung cancer therapeutics
        Scott, Fraser J.; Puig-Sellart, Mireia; Khalaf, Abedawn I.; Henderson, Catherine J.; Westrop, Gareth; Watson, David G.; Carter, Katharine; Grant, M. Helen; Suckling, Colin J.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2016), 26 (15), 3478-3486CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of 47 structurally diverse MGBs, derived from the natural product distamycin, was evaluated for anti-lung cancer activity by screening against the melanoma cancer cell line B16-F10. Five compds. have been found to possess significant activity, more so than a std. therapy, Gemcitabine. Moreover, one compd. has been found to have an activity around 70-fold that of Gemcitabine and has a favorable selectivity index of greater than 125. Furthermore, initial studies have revealed this compd. to be metabolically stable and thus it represents a lead for further optimization towards a novel treatment for lung cancer.

        Falconer, R. J.; Collins, B. M. Survey of the year 2009: applications of isothermal titration calorimetry. J. Mol. Recognit. 2011, 24, 1– 16,  DOI: 10.1002/jmr.1073
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Survey of the year 2009: applications of isothermal titration calorimetry
        Falconer, Robert J.; Collins, Brett M.
        Journal of Molecular Recognition (2011), 24 (1), 1-16CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        A review. Isothermal titrn. calorimetry (ITC) is now an established and invaluable method for detg. the thermodn. consts., assocn. const. and stoichiometry of mol. interactions in aq. solns. The technique has become widely used by biochemists to study protein interaction with other proteins, small mols., metal ions, lipids, nucleic acids and carbohydrates; and nucleic acid interaction with small mols. The drug discovery industry has utilized this approach to measure protein (or nucleic acid) interaction with drug candidates. ITC has been used to screen candidates, guide the design of potential drugs and validate the modeling used in structure-based drug design. Emerging disciplines including nanotechnol. and drug delivery could benefit greatly from ITC in enhancing their understanding and control of nano-particle assembly, and drug binding and controlled release. Copyright © 2010 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

      17. 17
        Treesuwan, W.; Wittayanarakul, K.; Anthony, N. G.; Huchet, G.; Alniss, H.; Hannongbua, S.; Khalaf, A. I.; Suckling, C. J.; Parkinson, J. A.; Mackay, S. P. A detailed binding free energy study of 2:1 ligand-DNA complex formation by experiment and simulation. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2009, 11, 10682– 10693,  DOI: 10.1039/b910574c
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        A detailed binding free energy study of 2 : 1 ligand-DNA complex formation by experiment and simulation
        Treesuwan, Witcha; Wittayanarakul, Kitiyaporn; Anthony, Nahoum G.; Huchet, Guillaume; Alniss, Hasan; Hannongbua, Supa; Khalaf, Abedawn I.; Suckling, Colin J.; Parkinson, John A.; Mackay, Simon P.
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2009), 11 (45), 10682-10693CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        In 2004, we used NMR to solve the structure of the minor groove binder thiazotropsin A bound in a 2:1 complex to the DNA duplex, d(CGACTAGTCG)2. In this current work, we have combined theory and expt. to confirm the binding thermodn. of this system. Mol. dynamics simulations that use polarizable or non-polarizable force fields with single and sep. trajectory approaches have been used to explore complexation at the mol. level. We have shown that the binding process invokes large conformational changes in both the receptor and ligand, which is reflected by large adaptation energies. This is compensated for by the net binding free energy, which is enthalpy driven and entropically opposed. Such a conformational change upon binding directly impacts on how the process must be simulated in order to yield accurate results. Our MM-PBSA binding calcns. from snapshots obtained from MD simulations of the polarizable force field using sep. trajectories yield an abs. binding free energy (-15.4 kcal mol-1) very close to that detd. by isothermal titrn. calorimetry (-10.2 kcal mol-1). Anal. of the major energy components reveals that favorable non-bonded van der Waals and electrostatic interactions contribute predominantly to the enthalpy term, while the unfavorable entropy appears to be driven by stabilization of the complex and the assocd. loss of conformational freedom. Our results have led to a deeper understanding of the nature of side-by-side minor groove ligand binding, which has significant implications for structure-based ligand development.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVajtbbO&md5=eec88170e8434c0b15c522b5fd0a00f3
      18. 18
        Chaires, J. B. A thermodynamic signature for drug-DNA binding mode. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2006, 453, 26– 31,  DOI: 10.1016/j.abb.2006.03.027
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        A thermodynamic signature for drug-DNA binding mode
        Chaires, Jonathan B.
        Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics (2006), 453 (1), 26-31CODEN: ABBIA4; ISSN:0003-9861. (Elsevier)
        A no. of small mols. bind directly and selectively to DNA, acting as chemotherapeutic agents by inhibiting replication, transcription or topoisomerase activity. Two common binding modes for these small mols. are intercalation or groove-binding. Intercalation results from insertion of a planar arom. substituent between DNA base pairs, with concomitant unwinding and lengthening of the DNA helix. Groove binding, in contrast, does not perturb the duplex structure to any great extent. Groove-binders are typically crescent-shaped, and fit snugly into the minor groove with little distortion of the DNA structure. Recent calorimetric studies have detd. the enthalpic and entropic contributions to the DNA binding of representative DNA binding compds. Anal. of such thermodn. data culled from the literature reveals distinctive thermodn. signatures for groove-binding and intercalating compds. Plots of the binding enthalpy (ΔH) against binding entropy (-TΔS) for 26 drug-DNA interactions reveal that groove-binding interactions are clustered in a region of the graph with favorable entropy contributions to the free energy, while intercalators are clustered in a region with unfavorable entropy but favorable enthalpy contributions. Groove-binding is predominantly entropically driven, while intercalation in enthalpically driven. The mol. basis of the contrasting thermodn. signatures for the two binding modes is by no means clear, but the pattern should be of use in categorizing new DNA binding agents.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XovVShs78%253D&md5=f09b638cc35d500cee86e172cc6a15e1
      19. 19
        Wittayanarakul, K.; Anthony, N. G.; Treesuwan, W.; Hannongbua, S.; Alniss, H.; Khalaf, A. I.; Suckling, C. J.; Parkinson, J. A.; Mackay, S. P. Ranking ligand affinity for the DNA minor groove by experiment and simulation. ACS Med. Chem. Lett. 2010, 1, 376– 380,  DOI: 10.1021/ml100047n
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Ranking Ligand Affinity for the DNA Minor Groove by Experiment and Simulation
        Wittayanarakul, Kitiyaporn; Anthony, Nahoum G.; Treesuwan, Witcha; Hannongbua, Supa; Alniss, Hasan; Khalaf, Abedawn I.; Suckling, Colin J.; Parkinson, John A.; Mackay, Simon P.
        ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2010), 1 (8), 376-380CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
        The structural and thermodn. basis for the strength and selectivity of the interactions of minor groove binders (MGBs) with DNA is not fully understood. In 2003, we reported the first example of a thiazole-contg. MGB that bound in a phase-shifted pattern that spanned six base pairs rather than the usual four (for tricyclic distamycin-like compds.). Since then, using DNA footprinting, NMR spectroscopy, isothermal titrn. calorimetry, and mol. dynamics, we have established that the flanking bases around the central four being read by the ligand have subtle effects on recognition. We have investigated the effect of these flanking sequences on binding and the reasons for the differences and established a computational method to rank ligand affinity against varying DNA sequences.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpsV2msbc%253D&md5=344a59659970f63f4776943e18a0d7b2
      20. 20
        Ababou, A.; Ladbury, J. E. Survey of the year 2004: literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry. J. Mol. Recognit. 2006, 19, 79– 89,  DOI: 10.1002/jmr.750
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Survey of the year 2004: Literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry
        Ababou, Abdessamad; Ladbury, John E.
        Journal of Molecular Recognition (2006), 19 (1), 79-89CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        A review. The market for com. available isothermal titrn. calorimeters continues to grow as new applications and methodologies are developed. Concomitantly the no. of users (and abusers) increases dramatically, resulting in a steady increase in the no. of publications in which isothermal titrn. calorimetry (ITC) plays a role. In the present review, we will focus on areas where ITC is making a significant contribution and will highlight some interesting applications of the technique. This overview of papers published in 2004 also discusses current issues of interest in the development of ITC as a tool of choice in the detn. of the thermodn. of mol. recognition and interaction.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XosFCksg%253D%253D&md5=ba1a7a5830d7f81ceb6bea494d327d44
      21. 21
        Cliff, M. J.; Gutierrez, A.; Ladbury, J. E. A survey of the year 2003 literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry. J. Mol. Recognit. 2004, 17, 513– 523,  DOI: 10.1002/jmr.714
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        A survey of the year 2003 literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry
        Cliff, Matthew J.; Gutierrez, Aldo; Ladbury, John E.
        Journal of Molecular Recognition (2004), 17 (6), 513-523CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        A review. Over the last decade isothermal titrn. calorimetry (ITC) has developed from a specialist method which was largely restricted in its use to dedicated experts, to a major, com. available tool in the arsenal directed at understanding mol. interactions. The no. of those proficient in this field has multiplied dramatically, as has the range of expts. to which this method has been applied. This has led to an overwhelming amt. of new data and novel applications to be assessed. With the increasing no. of publications in this field comes a need to highlight works of interest and impact. In this overview of the literature we have attempted to draw attention to papers and issues for which both the experienced calorimetrist and the interested dilettante hopefully will share our enthusiasm.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Cliff, M. J.; Ladbury, J. E. A survey of the year 2002 literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry. J. Mol. Recognit. 2003, 16, 383– 391,  DOI: 10.1002/jmr.648
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        A survey of the year 2002 literature on applications of isothermal titration calorimetry
        Cliff, Matthew J.; Ladbury, John E.
        Journal of Molecular Recognition (2003), 16 (6), 383-391CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        A review. Isothermal titrn. calorimetry (ITC) is becoming widely accepted as a key instrument in any lab. in which quantification of biomol. interactions is a requisite. The method has matured with respect to general acceptance and application development over recent years. The no. of publications on ITC has grown exponentially over the last 10 yr, reflecting the general utility of the method. Here all the published works of the year 2002 in this area have been surveyed. We review the broad range of systems to which ITC is being directed and classify these into general areas highlighting key publications of interest. This provides an overview of what can be achieved using this method and what developments are likely to occur in the near future.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXpvVyhsQ%253D%253D&md5=64d1b7b12bec81bb26ae99bbc7ce71fa
      23. 23
        Wiseman, T.; Williston, S.; Brandts, J. F.; Lin, L. N. Rapid measurement of binding constants and heats of binding using a new titration calorimeter. Anal. Biochem. 1989, 179, 131– 137,  DOI: 10.1016/0003-2697(89)90213-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Rapid measurement of binding constants and heats of binding using a new titration calorimeter
        Wiseman, Thomas; Williston, Samuel; Brandts, John F.; Lin, Lung Nan
        Analytical Biochemistry (1989), 179 (1), 131-7CODEN: ANBCA2; ISSN:0003-2697.
        A new titrn. calorimeter is described and results are presented for the binding of 2'-CMP to the active site of RNase A. The instrument characteristics include very high sensitivity, rapid calorimetric response, and fast thermal equilibration. Convenient software is available for instrument operation, data collection, data redn., and deconvolution to obtain least-squares ests. of binding parameters n, ΔH°, ΔS°, and the binding const. K. Sample through-put for the instrument is high, and under favorable conditions binding consts. as large as 108 M-1 can be measured. The bovine RNase A (RNase)/2'-CMP system was studied over a 50-fold range of RNase concn. and at 2 different temps. The binding consts. were in the 105 to 106 M-1 range, depending on conditions, and heats of binding ∼-15,000 cal/mol. Repeat detns. suggested errors of only a few percent in n, ΔH°, and K values over the most favorable concn. range.

        24
        Sensing the heat: the application of isothermal titration calorimetry to thermodynamic studies of biomolecular interactions
        Ladbury, John E.; Chowdhry, Babur Z.
        Chemistry & Biology (1996), 3 (10), 791-801CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Current Biology)
        Biomol. interactions can be defined by combining thermodn. data on the energetic properties of the interaction with high-resoln. structural data. The development of high sensitivity isothermal titrn. calorimetric equipment provides a dramatic advance in the gathering of thermodn. data, and the interactions between biol. macromols. can now be described with unprecedented accuracy.

      27. 27
        Breslauer, K. J.; Remeta, D. P.; Chou, W. Y.; Ferrante, R.; Curry, J.; Zaunczkowski, D.; Snyder, J. G.; Marky, L. A. Enthalpy-entropy compensations in drug-DNA binding studies. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987, 84, 8922– 8926,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.84.24.8922
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Enthalpy-entropy compensations in drug-DNA binding studies
        Breslauer, Kenneth J.; Remeta, David P.; Chou, Wan Yin; Ferrante, Robert; Curry, James; Zaunczkowski, Denise; Snyder, James G.; Marky, Luis A.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1987), 84 (24), 8922-6CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        A combination of spectroscopic and calorimetric techniques was used to characterize thermodynamically the DNA binding of netropsin and distamycin (2 minor groove-directed ligands), ethidium (an intercalator), and daunomycin (a combined intercalator/groove binder). Free energy data (ΔG°) show that each drug has similar binding affinities at 25° for the alternating copolymer duplex poly[d(A-T)]·poly[d(A-T)] and for the homopolymer duplex poly(dA)·poly(dT). However, calorimetric measurements reveal that the nature of the thermodn. forces (ΔH°, ΔS°) that drive drug binding to these 2 host duplexes at 25° are entirely different, despite similar binding ΔG° and similar salt dependencies (.vdelta.InK/.vdelta.In[Na+]). Specifically, the 25° binding of all 4 drugs to the alternating copolymer poly[d(A-T)]·poly[d(A-T)] is overwhelmingly enthalpy driven, whereas the corresponding binding of each drug to the homopolymer duplex poly(dA)·poly(dT) is overwhelmingly entropy driven. Thus, the similar binding ΔG° measured for complexation of each drug with poly[d(A-T)]·poly[d(A-T)] and poly(dA)·poly(dT) result from compensating changes in the enthalpy and entropy terms. Comparison with the thermodn. profiles for the complexation of these drug mols. to other DNA host duplexes at 25° reveals that the binding of each is strongly enthalpy driven, except when the poly(dA)·poly(dT) homopolymer serves as the host duplex. From this comparison it is concluded that poly[d(A-T)]·poly[d(A-T)] behaves thermodynamically as the more normal host duplex toward drug binding, whereas the entropy-driven binding to the poly(dA)·poly(dT) duplex represents aberrant behavior. Furthermore, since each of the 4 drugs has different modes of DNA binding, the obsd. entropy-driven behavior for binding to poly(dA)·poly(dT) reflects an intrinsic property of the homopolymer duplex that is perturbed in a common manner upon ligation rather than a common property of all 4 binding ligands. To rationalize the large pos. entropy changes that drive drug complexation with the poly(dA)·poly(dT) duplex, a model that emphasizes binding-induced perturbations of the more highly hydrated, altered B conformation of the homopolymer was proposed. The results suggest that an aberrant thermodn. binding profile may reflect an unusual DNA conformation in the host duplex. However, before such a conclusion can be reached, complete thermodn. binding profiles must be examd., since enthalpy-entropy compensations can cause 2 binding events to exhibit similar binding consts. even when they are driven by very different thermodn. forces.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXht1CntLw%253D&md5=65a3b61bdb0ce954c1e31c31d96bc9e3

        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      29. 29
        Naghibi, H.; Tamura, A.; Sturtevant, J. M. Significant discrepancies between van’t Hoff and calorimetric enthalpies. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995, 92, 5597– 5599,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.92.12.5597
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Significant discrepancies between van't Hoff and calorimetric enthalpies
        Naghibi, Hossein; Tamura, Atsuo; Sturtevant, Julian M.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1995), 92 (12), 5597-9CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        In this paper the authors show that the usual assumption in studies of the temp. variation of equil. consts. for equil. for the form A + B ↹ AB that a plot of In K vs. 1/T (K = equil. const., T = temp. in K) is a straight line with slope equal to -ΔHvH/R(ΔHvH = van't Hoff or apparently enthalpy, R = gas const.) is not valid in many cases. In all the cases considered here, ΔHvH is temp. dependent and is significantly different from the true or calorimetrically measured enthalpy, and the resp. values for ΔCp are also significantly different.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      35. 35
        Pelton, J. G.; Wemmer, D. E. Structural characterization of a 2:1 distamycin A.d(CGCAAATTGGC) complex by two-dimensional NMR. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989, 86, 5723– 5727,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.86.15.5723
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Structural characterization of a 2:1 distamycin A·d(CGCAAATTGGC) complex by two-dimensional NMR
        Pelton, Jeffrey G.; Wemmer, David E.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1989), 86 (15), 5723-7CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Two-dimensional NMR was used to study the 2:1 distamycin A·d(CGCAAATTGGC)·d(GCCAATTTGCG) complex. The NOE spectroscopy expt. was used to assign the arom. and C1'H DNA protons and to identify drug-DNA contacts. Two drug mols. bind simultaneously in the minor groove of the central 5'-AAATT-3' segment and are in close contact with both the DNA and 1 another. One drug binds with the formyl end close to the 2nd adenine base of the A-rich strand, whereas the other drug binds with the formyl end close to the 2nd adenine of the complementary strand. With this binding orientation, the pos. charged propylamidinium groups are directed toward opposite ends of the helix. Mol. modeling shows that the minor groove must expand relative to the 1:1 complex to accommodate both drugs. Energy calcns. suggest that electrostatic interactions, H bonds, and van der Waals forces contribute to the stability of the complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXls1KrsLc%253D&md5=8c601889773480c0bc12d262a26fefd9
      36. 36
        Mrksich, M.; Wade, W. S.; Dwyer, T. J.; Geierstanger, B. H.; Wemmer, D. E.; Dervan, P. B. A. 1992, 89, 7586– 7590,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.89.16.7586
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Antiparallel side-by-side dimeric motif for sequence-specific recognition in the minor groove of DNA by the designed peptide 1-methylimidazole-2-carboxamide netropsin
        Mrksich, Milan; Wade, Warren S.; Dwyer, Tammy J.; Geierstanger, Bernhard H.; Wemmer, David E.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1992), 89 (16), 7586-90CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        The designed peptide 1-methylimidazole-2-carboxamide netropsin (2-ImN) binds specifically to the sequence 5'-TGACT-3'. Direct evidence from NMR spectroscopy is presented that this synthetic ligand binds DNA as a 2:1 complex, which reveals that the structure is an antiparallel dimer in the minor groove of DNA. This is in contrast to the 1:1 complexes usually seen with most crescent-shaped minor groove binding mols. targeted toward A + T-rich tracts but reminiscent of a dimeric motif found for distamycin at high concns. These results suggest that sequence-dependent groove which may play an important role in allowing an expanded set of DNA binding motifs for synthetic peptides.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXks1ansr0%253D&md5=6b23e3f43bbdc1cb1239e6a3466be358
      37. 37
        White, S.; Szewczyk, J. W.; Turner, J. M.; Baird, E. E.; Dervan, P. B. Recognition of the four Watson-Crick base pairs in the DNA minor groove by synthetic ligands. Nature 1998, 391, 468– 471,  DOI: 10.1038/35106
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Recognition of the four Watson-Crick base pairs in the DNA minor groove by synthetic ligands
        White, Sarah; Szewczyk, Jason W.; Turner, James M.; Baird, Eldon E.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Nature (London) (1998), 391 (6666), 468-471CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        The design of synthetic ligands that read the information stored in the DNA double helix has been a long-standing goal at the interface of chem. and biol. Cell-permeable small mols. that target predetd. DNA sequences offer a potential approach for the regulation of gene expression. Oligodeoxynucleotides that recognize the major groove of double-helical DNA via triple-helix formation bind to a broad range of sequences with high affinity and specificity. Although oligonucleotides and their analogs have been shown to interfere with gene expression, the triple-helix approach is limited to recognition of purines and suffers from poor cellular uptake. The subsequent development of pairing rules for minor-groove binding polyamides contg. pyrrole (Py) and imidazole (Im) amino acids offers a second code to control sequence specificity. An Im/Py pair distinguishes G⪆C from C⪆G and both of these from A·T/T·A base pairs. A Py/Py pair specifies A,T from G,C but does not distinguish A·T from T·A. To break this degeneracy, we have added a new arom. amino acid, 3-hydroxypyrrole (Hp), to the repertoire to test for pairings that discriminate A·T from T⪆a. We find that replacement of a single hydrogen atom with a hydroxy group in a Hp/Py pairing regulates affinity and specificity by an order of magnitude. By incorporation of this third amino acid, hydroxypyrrole-imidazole-pyrrole polyamides form four ring-pairings (Im/Py, Py/Im, Hp/Py and Py/Hp) which distinguish all Four Watson-Crick base pairs in the minor groove of DNA.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXhtVemt78%253D&md5=38aa613c6a8afc2b933333f8779c392e
      38. 38
        Kostjukov, V. V.; Khomytova, N. M.; Davies, D. B.; Evstigneev, M. P. Electrostatic contribution to the energy of binding of aromatic ligands with DNA. Biopolymers 2008, 89, 680– 690,  DOI: 10.1002/bip.20985
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Electrostatic contribution to the energy of binding of aromatic ligands with DNA
        Kostjukov, V. V.; Khomytova, N. M.; Davies, D. B.; Evstigneev, M. P.
        Biopolymers (2008), 89 (8), 680-690CODEN: BIPMAA; ISSN:0006-3525. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        The method of soln. of the nonlinear Poisson-Boltzmann equation was used to calc. electrostatic energy of binding of various arom. ligands with DNA oligomers of different length. Anal. of the electrostatic contribution was made in terms of a two-step DNA binding process: formation of the intercalation cavity and insertion of the ligand. The total electrostatic energy was also partitioned into components: the energy of atom-atom coulombic interactions and the energy of interaction with surrounding water. The results indicate that electrostatic interactions are, as a whole, unfavorable to the intercalation process and that a correct anal. of structure-energy interrelation for Ligand-DNA interactions should only be accomplished at the level of the components rather than at the level of total electrostatic energy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXntVCks74%253D&md5=ba9bbf35332b4edcf34e457fb4a12b2f

        Dervan, P. B.; Burli, R. W. Sequence-specific DNA recognition by polyamides. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 1999, 3, 688– 693,  DOI: 10.1016/S1367-5931(99)00027-7

        39
        Sequence-specific DNA recognition by polyamides
        Dervan, Peter B.; Burli, Roland W.
        Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (1999), 3 (6), 688-693CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Current Biology Publications)
        A review, with 44 refs. Sequence-specific DNA-binding small mols. that can permeate cells could potentially regulate transcription of specific genes. Simple pairing rules for the minor groove of the double helix have been developed that allow the design of ligands such as polyamides for predetd. DNA sequences. Some of these polyamides have been shown to inhibit specific gene expression in mammalian cell culture.

        40
        DNA as a target for drug action
        Hurley, Laurence H.; Boyd, F. Leslie
        Trends in Pharmacological Sciences (1988), 9 (11), 402-7CODEN: TPHSDY; ISSN:0165-6147.
        A review with 31 refs. The appropriateness of the term 'receptor' for DNA with regard to antitumor drugs is discussed. Possible problems in designing drugs that will produce a defined pharmacol. response through interactions with DNA are also discussed along with structure-activity studies.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXjtlWmuw%253D%253D&md5=3ce301f8ff4c961f0ad903b52d6dc484
      41. 41
        Neidle, S. DNA minor-groove recognition by small molecules. Nat. Prod. Rep. 2001, 18, 291– 309,  DOI: 10.1039/a705982e
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        DNA minor-groove recognition by small molecules
        Neidle, Stephen
        Natural Product Reports (2001), 18 (3), 291-309CODEN: NPRRDF; ISSN:0265-0568. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review with 251 refs. covering literature up to 2000. The sequence selectivity inherent in even the simplest minor groove ligands has enabled them to be utilized as probes of DNA structure and dynamics. From this data has arisen the concept of devising sequence-specific agents capable of single-gene recognition, and thus of being targeted to single deleterious genes. Paradoxically, the "simple" ligands derived from the classic minor groove binders berenil, Hoechst 33258 and distamycin, which have only restricted sequence selectivity, can themselves show highly selective biol. effects, with some "drug-like" compds. having potential for anticancer and anti-PCP chemotherapy. In spite of this, the advantages of single-gene agents for mol. medicine in the future will dictate much of the future emphasis of this area, provided the formidable problems of converting them into pharmacol. acceptable drugs can be overcome.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXkslyisbw%253D&md5=63df932c2e44b24eb9b3edcc69d41707
      42. 42
        Chen, F. M.; Sha, F. Circular dichroic and kinetic differentiation of DNA binding modes of distamycin. Biochemistry 1998, 37, 11143– 11151,  DOI: 10.1021/bi980950l
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42
        Circular Dichroic and Kinetic Differentiation of DNA Binding Modes of Distamycin
        Chen, Fu-Ming; Sha, Feng
        Biochemistry (1998), 37 (32), 11143-11151CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
        DNA binding modes of distamycin (DST) were investigated via comparative binding studies with oligomeric duplexes of the form d(GCG-X-GCG)·d(CGC-Y-CGC), where Y is complementary to X and X = 4- or 5-base binding site. It was found that 1:1 and 2:1 drug-duplex complexes exhibit distinctly different circular dichroic (CD) spectral characteristics and can, thus, serve as diagnostic tools for binding mode differentiation. CD intensity profiles at 265 or 275 nm as a function of drug to DNA ratios can reveal the extent of binding cooperativity for 2:1 complex formation (i.e., the relative binding affinities of 2:1 vs. 1:1) at a 5-base-paired binding site. Comparison of these profiles leads to the following qual. ranking for the binding cooperativity for the studied sites: AAGTT, ATATA ≥ AAACT > AATAA, AAATA, AAAGT > AATAT > TAAAA ≥ AAATT ≥ AAAAA ≥ ATAAA, AAAAT. The plausibility of this ordering is strengthened by its agreement with the ranking established by earlier NMR studies on some of the sequences. The significantly slower DST dissocn. kinetics of the 2:1 complexes as compared to those of 1:1 made the kinetic measurements of SDS-induced dissocn. by the stopped-flow technique possible. The results indicate that the AAGTT site exhibits the slowest DST dissocn. rate, with a characteristic time of 35 s. The rates of dissocn. in general correlate reasonably well with the cooperativity order found via equil. CD measurements (the higher the binding cooperativity, the slower the rate of dissocn.). Base sequence specific binding of DST was also found for the 1:1 complex formation at the 4-base-paired sites, with AAAA, TTTT, ATTT, and AAAT sequences exhibiting the highest binding affinities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXks1ynurk%253D&md5=2fe3cecd2fcc7b6c746e3d058ed47744

      45. 45
        Bergqvist, S.; Williams, M. A.; O’Brien, R.; Ladbury, J. E. Heat capacity effects of water molecules and ions at a protein-DNA interface. J. Mol. Biol. 2004, 336, 829– 42,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jmb.2003.12.061
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Heat Capacity Effects of Water Molecules and Ions at a Protein-DNA Interface
        Bergqvist, Simon; Williams, Mark A.; O'Brien, Ronan; Ladbury, John E.
        Journal of Molecular Biology (2004), 336 (4), 829-842CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836. (Elsevier)
        The interaction of the TATA-box binding protein from the thermophilic and halophilic archaea Pyrococcus woesei (PwTBP) with an oligonucleotide contg. a specific binding site is stable over a very broad range of temps. and ionic strengths, and is consequently an outstanding system for characterizing general features of protein-DNA thermodn. In common with other specific protein-DNA recognition events, the PwTBP-TATA box interaction is accompanied by a large neg. change in heat capacity (ΔCp) arising from the total change in solvation that occurs upon binding, which in this case involves a net uptake of cations. Contrary to previous hypotheses, the authors find no overall effect of ionic strength on this heat capacity change. The authors investigate the local contributions of site-specific ion and water binding to the overall change in heat capacity by a series of site-directed mutations of PwTBP. The authors find that although changes in the local ion binding capacity affect the enthalpic and entropic contributions to the free energy of the interaction, they do not affect the change in heat capacity. In contrast, the authors find remarkably large heat capacity effects arising from two particular symmetry-related mutations. The great magnitude of these effects is not explicable in terms of current semi-empirical models of heat capacity change. Previously reported x-ray crystal structures show that these mutated residues are at the center of an evolutionarily conserved network of water-mediated hydrogen bonds between the protein and the DNA backbone. Consequently, the authors conclude that, in addn. to water mols. buried in the protein-DNA interface that have been previously shown to influence heat capacity, bridging water mols. in a highly polar surface environment can also contribute substantially to neg. heat capacity change on formation of a protein-DNA complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtV2nsr4%253D&md5=243098e407981e866be07f55fdff30cd
      46. 46

        48
        The role of water in protein-DNA interactions
        Schwabe, John W. R.
        Current Opinion in Structural Biology (1997), 7 (1), 126-134CODEN: COSBEF; ISSN:0959-440X. (Current Biology)
        A review, with 70 refs. It is becoming well accepted that water plays an important role in both the specificity and affinity of protein-DNA interactions. Recently, a combination of structural, biochem. and thermodn. techniques has particularly enhanced our understanding of the role of water in complexes between DNA and three different proteins: the trp repressor; the homeodomain; and the glucocorticoid receptor DNA-binding domain.

        Tanford, C. The hydrophobic effect and the organization of living matter. Science 1978, 200, 1012– 1018,  DOI: 10.1126/science.653353
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        The hydrophobic effect and the organization of living matter
        Tanford, Charles
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1978), 200 (4345), 1012-18CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        A review with 48 refs. Biol. organization may be viewed as consisting of 2 stages: biosynthesis and assembly. The assembly process is largely under thermodn. control. The hydrophobic effect is a unique organizing force. It is responsible for assembly of membranes of cells and intracellular compartments. The spontaneous folding of proteins, however, involves directed polar bonds, leading to more rigid structures. Intercellular organization probably involves polar bonds between cell surface proteins.

      51. 51
        Baginski, M.; Fogolari, F.; Briggs, J. M. Electrostatic and non-electrostatic contributions to the binding free energies of anthracycline antibiotics to DNA. J. Mol. Biol. 1997, 274, 253– 267,  DOI: 10.1006/jmbi.1997.1399
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Electrostatic and non-electrostatic contributions to the binding free energies of anthracycline antibiotics to DNA
        Baginski, Maciej; Fogolari, Federico; Briggs, James M.
        Journal of Molecular Biology (1997), 274 (2), 253-267CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836. (Academic Press Ltd.)
        The knowledge about mol. factors driving simple ligand-DNA interactions is still limited. The aim of the present study was to investigate the electrostatic and non-electrostatic contributions to the binding free energies of anthracycline compds. with DNA. Theor. calcns. based on continuum methods (Poisson-Boltzmann and solvent accessible surface area) were performed to est. the binding free energies of five selected anthracycline ligands (daunomycin, adriamycin, 9-deoxyadriamycin, hydroxyrubicin, and adriamycinone) to DNA. The free energy calcns. also took into account the conformational change that DNA undergoes upon ligand binding. This conformational change appeared to be very important for estg. abs. free energies of binding. Our studies revealed that the abs. values of all computed contributions to the binding free energy were quite large compared to the total free energy of binding. However, the sum of these large pos. and neg. values produced a small neg. value of the free energy around -10 kcal/mol. This value is in good agreement with exptl. data. Exptl. values for relative binding free energies were also reproduced for charged ligands by our calcns. Together, it was found that the driving force for ligand-DNA complex formation is the non-polar interaction between the ligand and DNA even if the ligand is pos. charged.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        A review with 177 refs. Electrostatics play a vital role in intra- and intermol. interactions in chem. and biochem. Intramol. interactions are complicated by quantum mech. effects. Intermol. interactions are dominated by electrostatic forces. Current methods for modeling electrostatic interactions are examd.

The authors propose that these data - particularly the change in enthalpy - could provide a valuable, complementary addn. to established tools for selecting compds. in lead discovery and for aiding lead optimization.

        Drew, H. R.; Dickerson, R. E. Structure of a B-DNA dodecamer. III. Geometry of hydration. J. Mol. Biol. 1981, 151, 535– 556,  DOI: 10.1016/0022-2836(81)90009-7
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Structure of a B-DNA dodecamer. III. Geometry of hydration
        Drew, Horace R.; Dickerson, Richard E.
        Journal of Molecular Biology (1981), 151 (3), 535-56CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836.
        The B-DNA dodecamer, C-G-C-G-A-A-T-T-C-G-C-G, crystd. as slightly more than 1 full turn of right-handed B-DNA in space group P212121 with cell dimensions a = 24.87 Å, b = 40.39 Å, and c = 66.20 Å. X-ray anal. showed that it was surrounded by 72 ordered water mols., mostly assocd. with polar N and O atoms at exposed edges of base-pairs. Hydration in the major groove was mainly in the form of a monodentate monolayer. Hydration of backbone phosphate O atoms were not ordered, except when immobilized by the 5-Me groups of adjacent thymines. The minor groove was extensively and regularly hydrated, with a zigzag spine of 1st- and 2nd-shell hydration along the floor of the groove serving as a foundation for less-regular outer shells extending beyond the radius of the phosphate backbone. The spine network bridged purine N-3 and pyrimidine O-2 atoms in adjacent base pairs; it was regular in the A-A-T-T center, but was disrupted at the C-G-C-G ends, partly by the guanine N-2 amino groups. The minor groove hydration spine may be responsible for the stability of the B form of polymers contg. only A-T and I-C base pairs, and its disruption may explain the ease of transition to the A form of polymers with G-C pairs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL38XmsVentg%253D%253D&md5=4378664a4da9ec83155a3f7e046027d9

        Nickols, N. G.; Szablowski, J. O.; Hargrove, A. E.; Li, B. C.; Raskatov, J. A.; Dervan, P. B. Activity of a Py-Im polyamide targeted to the estrogen response element. Mol. Cancer Ther. 2013, 12, 675– 684,  DOI: 10.1158/1535-7163.MCT-12-1040
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        58
        Activity of a Py-Im Polyamide Targeted to the Estrogen Response Element
        Nickols, Nicholas G.; Szablowski, Jerzy O.; Hargrove, Amanda E.; Li, Benjamin C.; Raskatov, Jevgenij A.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Molecular Cancer Therapeutics (2013), 12 (5), 675-684CODEN: MCTOCF; ISSN:1535-7163. (American Association for Cancer Research)
        Pyrrole-imidazole (Py-Im) polyamides are a class of programmable DNA minor groove binders capable of modulating the activity of DNA-binding proteins and affecting changes in gene expression. Estrogen receptor alpha (ERα) is a ligand-activated hormone receptor that binds as a homodimer to estrogen response elements (ERE) and is a driving oncogene in a majority of breast cancers. We tested a selection of structurally similar Py-Im polyamides with differing DNA sequence specificity for activity against 17β-estadiol (E2)-induced transcription and cytotoxicity in ERα pos., E2-stimulated T47DKBluc cells, which express luciferase under ERα control. The most active polyamide targeted the sequence 5'-WGGWCW-3' (W = A or T), which is the canonical ERE half site. Whole transcriptome anal. using RNA-Seq revealed that treatment of E2-stimulated breast cancer cells with this polyamide reduced the effects of E2 on the majority of those most strongly affected by E2 but had much less effect on the majority of E2-induced transcripts. In vivo, this polyamide circulated at detectable levels following s.c. injection and reduced levels of ER-driven luciferase expression in xenografted tumors in mice after s.c. compd. administration without significant host toxicity. Mol Cancer Ther; 12(5); 675-84. ©2013 AACR.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXntlSisLw%253D&md5=c6a2d78b3796ff1ab436743a3dc62656

        Nickols, N. G.; Dervan, P. B. Suppression of androgen receptor-mediated gene expression by a sequence-specific DNA-binding polyamide. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2007, 104, 10418– 10423,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0704217104
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        Suppression of androgen receptor-mediated gene expression by a sequence-specific DNA-binding polyamide
        Nickols, Nicholas G.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2007), 104 (25), 10418-10423CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        Androgen receptor (AR) is essential for the growth and progression of prostate cancer in both hormone-sensitive and hormone-refractory disease. A DNA-binding polyamide that targets the consensus androgen response element binds the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) promoter androgen response element, inhibits androgen-induced expression of PSA and several other AR-regulated genes in cultured prostate cancer cells, and reduces AR occupancy at the PSA promoter and enhancer. Down-regulation of PSA by this polyamide was comparable to that produced by the synthetic antiandrogen bicalutamide (Casodex) at the same concn. Genome-wide expression anal. reveals that a similar no. of transcripts are affected by treatment with the polyamide and with bicalutamide. Direct inhibition of the AR-DNA interface by sequence-specific DNA binding small mols. could offer an alternative approach to antagonizing AR activity.

      62. 62
        Sessa, C.; Pagani, O.; Zurlo, M. G.; de Jong, J.; Hofmann, C.; Lassus, M.; Marrari, P.; Strolin Benedetti, M.; Cavalli, F. Phase I study of the novel distamycin derivative tallimustine (FCE 24517). Annals of oncology: official journal of the European Society for Medical Oncology 1994, 5, 901– 907,  DOI: 10.1093/oxfordjournals.annonc.a058728
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62
        Phase I study of the novel distamycin derivative tallimustine (FCE 24517)
        Sessa C; Pagani O; Zurlo M G; de Jong J; Hofmann C; Lassus M; Marrari P; Strolin Benedetti M; Cavalli F
        Annals of oncology : official journal of the European Society for Medical Oncology (1994), 5 (10), 901-7 ISSN:0923-7534.
        BACKGROUND: Tallimustine, a benzoyl nitrogen mustard derivative of the antiviral agent distamycin A, is a new alkylating agent which binds to A-T rich regions of DNA in the minor groove producing highly sequence-specific alkylations. Its main preclinical features are a significant antitumor activity in animal models and a lack of cross-resistance in vitro and in vivo with L-PAM. Myelotoxicity was dose-limiting in animals, with a more than 100-fold difference in bone marrow sensitivity between mice and dogs. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Forty adult patients (pts) with solid malignancies were entered in the study. The drug was administered as an IV bolus every 4 weeks. CBC was repeated twice a week and serial assessments of renal function were performed in the week following the first cycle. From the starting dose of 50 micrograms/m2, corresponding to 1/3 of the highest non-toxic dose (HNTD) in dogs, there were increases through 10 dose levels, with reliance only on the features of the myelotoxicity observed. RESULTS: The main toxic effect was neutropenia which was dose-limiting, selective and short-lasting. Only previously-untreated pts received doses of 750 micrograms/m2 or more, with grade 4 neutropenia occurring in > or = 75% of the cycles. The maximally tolerable dose (MTD) was defined as 1250 micrograms/m2, with 3 of 3 pts developing febrile neutropenia requiring IV antibiotics. A platelet count of < 100 x 10(3)/microliters was observed in only one pt. Bone marrow aspiration performed in selected pts on days 8 and 15 confirmed a highly selective impairment by tallimustine of the myeloid lineage, with rapid recovery of the proliferative compartment. Pharmacokinetic studies performed at 1000 micrograms/m2 and 1250 micrograms/m2 showed a rapid fall of the plasma levels within the first 2 hours with drug concentrations between 100 ng/ml and 400 ng/ml within the first hour. A partial response of 4 months' duration was reported in one previously-untreated pt with cutaneous recurrences of malignant mesothelioma. CONCLUSIONS: The report of some antitumour efficacy, the high selectivity of neutropenia, the lack of significant non-hematological toxic effects and the occurrence of detectable but still low plasma drug concentrations suggest that further clinical evaluation of higher doses of tallimustine in combination with colony-stimulating factors would be justified.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK2M3htVWntg%253D%253D&md5=25e16360021d029e1004e60da2f5c413

      65. 65
        Rahman, K. M.; Thompson, A. S.; James, C. H.; Narayanaswamy, M.; Thurston, D. E. The pyrrolobenzodiazepine dimer SJG-136 forms sequence-dependent intrastrand DNA cross-links and monoalkylated adducts in addition to interstrand cross-links. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 13756– 13766,  DOI: 10.1021/ja902986x
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65
        The pyrrolobenzodiazepine dimer SJG-136 forms sequence-dependent intrastrand DNA cross-links and monoalkylated adducts in addition to interstrand cross-links
        Rahman, Khondaker M.; Thompson, Andrew S.; James, Colin H.; Narayanaswamy, Mathangi; Thurston, David E.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (38), 13756-13766CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        SJG-136 (1) is a sequence-selective DNA-interactive agent that is about to enter phase II clin. trials. Using a HPLC/MS-based methodol. developed to evaluate the binding of DNA-interactive agents to oligonucleotides of varying length and sequence, we have demonstrated that, in addn. to the previously known interstrand cross-link at Pu-GATC-Py sequences, 1 can form a longer interstrand cross-link at Pu-GAATC-Py sequences, an intrastrand cross-link at both shorter Pu-GATG-Py and longer Pu-GAATG-Py sequences, and, in addn., monoalkylated adducts at suitable PBD binding sites where neither intra- or interstrand cross-links are feasible because of the unavailability of two appropriately positioned guanines. Crucially, we have demonstrated a preference for the extended intrastrand cross-link with Pu-GAATG-Py, which forms more rapidly than the other cross-links (rank order: Pu-GAATG-Py > Pu-GATC-Py » Pu-GATG-Py and Pu-GAATC-Py). However, thermal denaturation studies suggest that the originally reported Pu-GATC-Py interstrand cross-link is more stable, consistent with the covalent joining of both strands of the duplex and a lower overall distortion of the helix according to modeling studies. These observations impact on the proposed mechanism of action of SJG-136 (1) both in vitro and in vivo, the repair of its adducts and mechanism of resistance in cells, and potentially on the type of pharmacodynamic assay used in clin. trials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtV2mur3I&md5=93600bf22d2d303a9dc9687e395307fa
      66. 66
        Janjigian, Y. Y.; Lee, W.; Kris, M. G.; Miller, V. A.; Krug, L. M.; Azzoli, C. G.; Senturk, E.; Calcutt, M. W.; Rizvi, N. A. A phase I trial of SJG-136 (NSC#694501) in advanced solid tumors. Cancer Chemother. Pharmacol. 2010, 65, 833– 838,  DOI: 10.1007/s00280-009-1088-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        A phase I trial of SJG-136 (NSC#694501) in advanced solid tumors
        Janjigian, Yelena Y.; Lee, Wooin; Kris, Mark G.; Miller, Vincent A.; Krug, Lee M.; Azzoli, Christopher G.; Senturk, Emir; Wade Calcutt, M.; Rizvi, Naiyer A.
        Cancer Chemotherapy and Pharmacology (2010), 65 (5), 833-838CODEN: CCPHDZ; ISSN:0344-5704. (Springer)
        Purpose: SJG-136 is a pyrrolobenzodiazepine dimer that forms DNA crosslinks and has demonstrated broad antitumor activity. We undertook this trial to det. the max.-tolerated dose (MTD), toxicities and pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of SJG-136 in patients with an advanced solid tumor. Patients and methods: In this phase I study, patients were treated with SJG-136 on days 1, 8 and 15 of a 28-day cycle. Dose levels studied were 10, 20, 40 and 60 μg/m2. PK parameters of SJG-136 were assessed following the i.v. administration of SJG-136 on days 1 and 15 of cycle 1. Results: Twenty-one patients with advanced solid tumors were treated. Patients had a median of two prior chemotherapy regimens. Fatigue was dose-limiting with SJG-136 60 μg/m2/day administered on days 1, 8 and 15 of a 28-day cycle. Grade 3 thrombocytopenia and delayed onset liver toxicity were seen in one patient each. PK parameters of SJG-136 indicated dose-proportional increases in systemic exposure with increasing doses. No objective responses were seen. Conclusion: For patients with advanced solid tumors, the MTD of SJG-136 is 40 μg/m2/day administered on days 1, 8 and 15 of a 28-day cycle. The major dose limiting toxicity was fatigue. Alternative dosing strategies are now being evaluated.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXit1GmtL0%253D&md5=faae5e4cfbc4416712c6a15b77120410
      67. 67
        Geierstanger, B. H.; Mrksich, M.; Dervan, P. B.; Wemmer, D. E. Design of a G.C-specific DNA minor groove-binding peptide. Science 1994, 266, 646– 650,  DOI: 10.1126/science.7939719
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Design of a G·C-specific DNA minor groove-binding peptide
        Geierstanger, Bernhard H.; Mrksich, Milan; Dervan, Peter B.; Wemmer, David E.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1994), 266 (5185), 646-50CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A four-ring tripeptide contg. alternating imidazole and pyrrole carboxamides specifically binds six-base pair 5'-(A,T)GCGC(A,T)-3' sites in the minor groove of DNA. The designed peptide has a specificity completely reversed from that of the tripyrrole distamycin, which binds A,T sequences. Structural studies with NMR revealed that two peptides bound side-by-side and in an antiparallel orientation in the minor groove. Each of the four imidazoles in the 2:1 ligand-DNA complex recognized a specific guanine amino group in the GCGC core through a hydrogen bond. Targeting a designated four-base pair G·C tract by this synthetic ligand supports the generality of the 2:1 peptide-DNA motif for sequence-specific minor groove recognition of DNA.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXitVCltLg%253D&md5=69a6ff67062119186a427cb69d38d59b

        A review with 300 refs. on the binding of drugs and other substances to DNA via intercalation and minor groove binding.

      71. 71
        Chaires, J. B.; Leng, F.; Przewloka, T.; Fokt, I.; Ling, Y. H.; Perez-Soler, R.; Priebe, W. Structure-based design of a new bisintercalating anthracycline antibiotic. J. Med. Chem. 1997, 40, 261– 266,  DOI: 10.1021/jm9607414
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        71
        Structure-Based Design of a New Bisintercalating Anthracycline Antibiotic
        Chaires, Jonathan B.; Leng, Fenfei; Przewloka, Teresa; Fokt, Izabela; Ling, Yi-He; Perez-Soler, Roman; Priebe, Waldemar
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1997), 40 (3), 261-266CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A new bisintercalating anthracycline antibiotic, WP631, has been designed and synthesized. The rational design of the new compd. was based upon the geometry of monomeric anthracyclines bound to DNA oligonucleotides obsd. in high-resoln. crystal structures. Monomeric units of daunorubicin have been linked through their reactive 3' NH2 substituents on the daunosamine moieties to form the new bisanthracycline WP631. Viscosity studies confirmed that WP631 binds to DNA by bisintercalation. Differential scanning calorimetry and UV melting expts. were used to measure the ultratight binding of WP631 to DNA. The binding const. for the interaction of WP631 with herring sperm DNA was detd. to be 2.7×1011 M-1 at 20°. The large, favorable binding free energy of -15.3 kcal mol-1 was found to result from a large, neg. enthalpic contribution of -30.2 kcal mol-1. A mol. model was generated that shows the favorable stereochem. fit of the linker in the DNA minor groove. The cytotoxicity of WP631 was compared to that of doxorubicin using MCF-7-sensitive and MCF-7/VP-16 MRP-mediated multidrug-resistant cell lines. These initial studies showed that while WP631 is slightly less cytotoxic than doxorubicin in the sensitive cell line, it appears to overcome MRP-mediated multidrug resistance and was much more cytotoxic against the MCF-7/VP-16 cell line than was doxorubicin. The design of new potential anticancer agents based on known structural principles was found to produce a compd. with significantly increased DNA binding affinity and with interesting biol. activity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXktFyrsQ%253D%253D&md5=222984c9e2d6c619e0062b20f51589d7

        Bremer, R. E.; Szewczyk, J. W.; Baird, E. E.; Dervan, P. B. Recognition of the DNA minor groove by pyrrole-imidazole polyamides: comparison of desmethyl- and N-methylpyrrole. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2000, 8, 1947– 1955,  DOI: 10.1016/S0968-0896(00)00145-0

      73. 73
        Anthony, N. G.; Breen, D.; Clarke, J.; Donoghue, G.; Drummond, A. J.; Ellis, E. M.; Gemmell, C. G.; Helesbeux, J. J.; Hunter, I. S.; Khalaf, A. I.; Mackay, S. P.; Parkinson, J. A.; Suckling, C. J.; Waigh, R. D. Antimicrobial lexitropsins containing amide, amidine, and alkene linking groups. J. Med. Chem. 2007, 50, 6116– 6125,  DOI: 10.1021/jm070831g
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        73
        Antimicrobial Lexitropsins Containing Amide, Amidine, and Alkene Linking Groups
        Anthony, Nahoum G.; Breen, David; Clarke, Joanna; Donoghue, Gavin; Drummond, Allan J.; Ellis, Elizabeth M.; Gemmell, Curtis G.; Helesbeux, Jean-Jacques; Hunter, Iain S.; Khalaf, Abedawn I.; Mackay, Simon P.; Parkinson, John A.; Suckling, Colin J.; Waigh, Roger D.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2007), 50 (24), 6116-6125CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis and properties of 80 short minor groove binders, such as I, related to distamycin and the thiazotropsins were described. The design of the compds. was principally predicated upon increased affinity arising from hydrophobic interactions between minor groove binders and DNA. The introduction of hydrophobic arom. head groups, including quinolyl and benzoyl derivs., and of alkenes as linkers led to several strongly active antibacterial compds. with MIC for Staphylococcus aureus, both methicillin-sensitive and -resistant strains, in the range of 0.1-5 μg mL-1, which is comparable to many established antibacterial agents. Antifungal activity was also found in the range of 20-50 μg mL-1 MIC against Aspergillus niger and Candida albicans, again comparable with established antifungal drugs. A quinoline deriv. was found to protect mice against S. Aureus infection for a period of up to six days after a single i.p. dose of 40 mg kg-1.

        Hsu, C. F.; Phillips, J. W.; Trauger, J. W.; Farkas, M. E.; Belitsky, J. M.; Heckel, A.; Olenyuk, B. Z.; Puckett, J. W.; Wang, C. C.; Dervan, P. B. Completion of a Programmable DNA-Binding Small Molecule Library. Tetrahedron 2007, 63, 6146– 6151,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2007.03.041
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Completion of a programmable DNA-binding small molecule library
        Hsu, Carey F.; Phillips, John W.; Trauger, John W.; Farkas, Michelle E.; Belitsky, Jason M.; Heckel, Alexander; Olenyuk, Bogdan Z.; Puckett, James W.; Wang, Clay C. C.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Tetrahedron (2007), 63 (27), 6146-6151CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Hairpin pyrrole-imidazole (Py-Im) polyamides are programmable oligomers that bind the DNA minor groove in a sequence-specific manner with affinities comparable to those of natural DNA-binding proteins. These cell-permeable small mols. have been shown to enter the nuclei of live cells and downregulate endogenous gene expression. We complete here a library of 27 hairpin Py-Im polyamides, which bind seven-base-pair sequences of the general form 5'-WWGNNNW-3' (where W=A or T, N=W, G, or C). Their equil. assocn. consts. (Ka) range from Ka=1×108 to 4×1010 M-1 with good sequence specificity. A table of binding affinities and sequence contexts for this completed 27-member library has been assembled for the benefit of the chem. biol. community interested in mol. control of transcription.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      76. 76
        Kwong, P. D.; Doyle, M. L.; Casper, D. J.; Cicala, C.; Leavitt, S. A.; Majeed, S.; Steenbeke, T. D.; Venturi, M.; Chaiken, I.; Fung, M.; Katinger, H.; Parren, P. W.; Robinson, J.; Van Ryk, D.; Wang, L.; Burton, D. R.; Freire, E.; Wyatt, R.; Sodroski, J.; Hendrickson, W. A.; Arthos, J. HIV-1 evades antibody-mediated neutralization through conformational masking of receptor-binding sites. Nature 2002, 420, 678– 682,  DOI: 10.1038/nature01188
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        HIV-1 evades antibody-mediated neutralization through conformational masking of receptor-binding sites
        Kwong, Peter D.; Doyle, Michael L.; Casper, David J.; Cicala, Claudia; Leavitt, Stephanie A.; Majeed, Shahzad; Steenbeke, Tavis D.; Venturi, Miro; Chaiken, Irwin; Fung, Michael; Katinger, Hermann; Parren, Paul W. I. H.; Robinson, James; Van Ryk, Donald; Wang, Liping; Burton, Dennis R.; Freire, Ernesto; Wyatt, Richard; Sodroski, Joseph; Hendrickson, Wayne A.; Arthos, James
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2002), 420 (6916), 678-682CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The ability of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) to persist and cause AIDS is dependent on its avoidance of antibody-mediated neutralization. The virus elicits abundant, envelope-directed antibodies that have little neutralization capacity. This lack of neutralization is paradoxical, given the functional conservation and exposure of receptor-binding sites on the gp120 envelope glycoprotein, which are larger than the typical antibody footprint and should therefore be accessible for antibody binding. Because gp120-receptor interactions involve conformational reorganization, the authors measured the entropies of binding for 20 gp120-reactive antibodies. Here they show that recognition by receptor-binding-site antibodies induces conformational change. Correlation with neutralization potency and anal. of receptor-antibody thermodn. cycles suggested a receptor-binding-site conformational masking mechanism of neutralization escape. To understand how such an escape mechanism would be compatible with virus-receptor interactions, the authors tested a sol. dodecameric receptor mol. and found that it neutralized primary HIV-1 isolates with great potency, showing that simultaneous binding of viral envelope glycoproteins by multiple receptors creates sufficient avidity to compensate for such masking. Because this soln. is available for cell-surface receptors but not for most antibodies, conformational masking enables HIV-1 to maintain receptor binding and simultaneously to resist neutralization.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XpsVSitbo%253D&md5=950eda99b878789b1efca4250fcb8abd

      79. 79
        Chenoweth, D. M.; Dervan, P. B. Allosteric modulation of DNA by small molecules. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2009, 106, 13175– 1319,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0906532106
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Allosteric modulation of DNA by small molecules
        Chenoweth, David M.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2009), 106 (32), 13175-13179, S13175/1-S13175/10CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        Many human diseases are caused by dysregulated gene expression. The oversupply of transcription factors may be required for the growth and metastatic behavior of human cancers. Cell perscription factor-DNA interfaces could silence aberrant gene expression pathways. Pyrrole-imidazole polyamides are DNA minor-groove binding mols. that are programmable for a large repertoire of DNA motifs. A high resoln. X-ray crystal structure of an 8-ring cyclic Py/Im polyamide bound to the central 6 bp of the sequence d(5'-CCAGGCCTGG-3')2 reveals a 4 Å widening of the minor groove and compression of the major groove along with a > 18° bend in the helix axis toward the major groove. This allosteric perturbation of the DNA helix provides a mol. basis for disruption of transcription factor-DNA interfaces by small mols., a min. step in chem. control of gene networks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtVOisbfL&md5=f0d7c333e55a8bd2c721a17e8d0c3e7b
      80. 80
        Crick, F. Central dogma of molecular biology. Nature 1970, 227, 561– 563,  DOI: 10.1038/227561a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        80
        Central dogma of molecular biology
        Crick, Francis H. C.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1970), 227 (5258), 561-3CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        The history of the central dogma of mol. biol., which states that residue-by-residue transfer of sequential information cannot occur from protein to protein or to nucleic acid, is presented; and the 9 possible transfers are tentatively regrouped into 3 classes: general, special, and unknown transfers (those postulated by the central dogma). The general transfers, DNA → DNA (the arrow represents directional flow of detailed sequence information), DNA → RNA, and RNA → protein, are those that can occur in all cells. Special transfers, RNA → RNA, RNA → DNA, and DNA → protein, may occur in special circumstances. Unknown transfers, protein → protein, protein → DNA, protein → RNA, the central dogma postulates, never occur. The current validity of the central dogma is discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3cXltVGgtLw%253D&md5=ed1c1371c5593a29eaab6937a9338f96
      81. 81
        Dervan, P. B. Design of sequence-specific DNA-binding molecules. Science 1986, 232, 464– 471,  DOI: 10.1126/science.2421408
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        81
        Design of sequence-specific DNA-binding molecules
        Dervan, Peter B.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1986), 232 (4749), 464-71CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        A review with 66 refs. Base sequence information can be stored in the local structure of right-handed double-helical DNA (B-DNA). The question arises as to whether a set of rules for the 3-dimensional readout of the B-DNA helix can be developed. This would allow the design of synthetic mols. that bind DNA of any specific sequence and site size. There for 4 stages of development for each new synthetic sequence-specific DNA-binding mol.: design, synthesis, testing for sequence specificity, and reevaluation of the design. This approach has produced bis(distamycin)fumaramide, a synthetic crescent-shaped oligopeptide that binds 9 contiguous adenine-thymine base pairs in the minor groove of double-helical DNA.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        84
        Molecular recognition of DNA by small molecules
        Dervan, P. B.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2001), 9 (9), 2215-2235CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review with refs. on the development of a universal chem. code with a common shape for recognizing any linear combination of Watson-Crick base pairs, taking into consideration the sequence-dependent microstructure of DNA. In addn. to a brief historical review, a discussion of the pairing rules for minor groove recognition and the regulation of gene expression by small mols. is presented.

        Trauger, J. W.; Baird, E. E.; Dervan, P. B. Recognition of DNA by designed ligands at subnanomolar concentrations. Nature 1996, 382, 559– 561,  DOI: 10.1038/382559a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        87
        Recognition of DNA by designed ligands at subnanomolar concentrations
        Trauger, John W.; Baird, Eldon E.; Dervan, Peter B.
        Nature (London) (1996), 382 (6591), 559-561CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        Small mols. that specifically bind with high affinity to any predetd. DNA sequence in the human genome would be useful tools in mol. biol. and potentially in human medicine. Simple rules have been developed to control rationally the sequence specificity of minor-groove-binding polyamides contg. N-methylimidazole and N-methylpyrrole amino acids. Two eight-ring pyrrole-imidazole polyamides differing in sequence by a single amino acid bind specifically to resp. six-base-pair target sites which differ in sequence by a single base pair. Binding is obsd. at subnanomolar concns. of ligand. The replacement of a single nitrogen atom with a C-H regulates affinity and specificity by two orders of magnitude. The broad range of sequences that can be specifically targeted with pyrrole-imidazole polyamides, coupled with an efficient solid-phase synthesis methodol., identify a powerful class of small mols. for sequence-specific recognition of double-helical DNA.
